text: In mathematics, specifically in the field of group theory, the McKay Conjecture is a conjecture of equality between the number of irreducible complex characters of degree not divisible by a prime number p to that of the normalizer of a Sylow p-subgroup. It is named after Canadian mathematician John McKay. == Statement == Suppose p is a prime number, G is a finite group, and P \leq G is a Sylow p-subgroup. Define :\textrm{Irr}_{p'}(G) := \\{\chi \in \textrm{Irr}(G) : p mid \chi(1) \\} where \textrm{Irr}(G) denotes the set of complex irreducible characters of the group G. The McKay conjecture claims the equality :|\textrm{Irr}_{p'}(G)| = |\textrm{Irr}_{p'}(N_G(P))| where N_G(P) is the normalizer of P in G. == References == * (Corrected reprint of the 1976 original, published by Academic Press.) * Category:Representation theory of groups
title: McKay conjecture
